text.0: .@EnlaceLatinoNC served their Spanish-speaking audience directly: “The Latino community needs more information that is practical, reliable, & useful. Voter education & addressing the ‘what, where and how’ of the election process is essential for greater electoral participation.”
text.1: Join us and these newsrooms tomorrow to learn more about these incredible projects. RSVP now: https://t.co/FCVDGZdUUm
text.2: .@KALW took multiple approaches to meet communities across the Bay Area where they were at with critical information about voting and key local and statewide ballot initiatives.
text.3: .@PhillyInquirer translated their comprehensive FAQ on voting into five languages to better serve folks across their community.
text.4: .@MSFreePress combined data w/ audience-driven solutions: “We found that the participants were very aware of probable problems around voting, but...felt powerless to find & institute solutions. They were very excited to have a platform to speak where we were [directly] listening"
text.5: .@Freep devoted significant resources to arresting the spread of false information: “Prioritizing provenance & networks in our reporting [on misinformation] and differentiating this work from traditional fact-checking...really resonated with people across the political spectrum.”
text.6: .@ColoradoSun let audiences guide coverage: “The most important takeaway from the audience listening... is that no question or topic is too basic. This discovery reoriented our entire approach, shifting the focus to explaining the basics, such as how to fix mistakes on a ballot"
text.7: .@Scalawag relied on their audiences across the South to shape their coverage: “The conversations we had and the tips we gathered from [audience] texts directly informed us on what to report on—helping us with that ongoing question of prioritization in up-to-the-minute coverage.”
text.8:
This year, we gave 36 newsrooms small grants to cover the election in new & innovative ways. Tomorrow, 7 of them will share how they did it & how you can copy them.

Get a sneak peek below of the major lessons learned & RSVP now for tomorrow's event: https://t.co/FCVDGZdUUm
text.9:
Our upcoming "Election 2020: Lessons Learned" event will feature 7 local newsrooms sharing tips on: 

- Voter guides
- Explanatory coverage
- Content translation
- False info
- Election data viz 
- Listening to audiences

RSVP now to join the discussion: https://t.co/FCVDGZdUUm
text.10:
Journalists!

Long-term thinking is non-negotiable when it comes to trust.

That's why we are hosting a monthlong online course that will give you research-backed strategies.

Apply by Jan. 4!  https://t.co/kf0c3VkNyL https://t.co/utPtinHRmX
